skill.description: Create and modify Argcfiles using the special syntax required. Use this when editing Argcfile.sh, @argc, or any shell script that contains `argc --argc-eval`.

security_audit.summary: This is a pure documentation skill with no executable code, scripts, network operations, or file access capabilities. The skill provides informational content about the argc Bash framework and contains example code for educational purposes only.

content.value_statement: Creating command-line interfaces in Bash is complex and error-prone. This skill teaches you to use argc, a framework that uses special comment syntax to automatically generate argument parsers, help docs, and subcommand handlers.
actual_capabilities: Generate Bash argument parsers using comment tags
Define options, flags, and positional arguments
limitations: Requires argc binary to be installed
Does not execute or test argc scripts
Cannot generate new files without user confirmation

best_practices: Use ${argc_foo:-default} pattern for optional values to prevent unbound variable errors
Place @meta require-tools at subcommand level to check dependencies only when needed
Add value notation like <PATH> or <FILE> to document expected argument types
anti_patterns: Using positional arguments when named options would be clearer for users
Omitting @describe so users have no help text for the command
Not checking if argc is installed before running the eval command

faq.question: Does argc work with other shells like Zsh or Fish?
faq.answer: Argc is designed specifically for Bash. Other shells require different argument parsing approaches.

faq.question: What is the maximum number of arguments supported?
faq.answer: Argc has no hard limit but very large argument counts may hit shell buffer restrictions.

faq.question: Can argc integrate with existing shell functions?
faq.answer: Yes, argc can call your existing bash functions and use them for defaults or choices.

faq.question: Is my data safe when using argc?
faq.answer: Argc only processes command-line arguments locally. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why does my script fail with unbound variable error?
faq.answer: Use ${argc_var:-default} pattern or set -u may need adjustment for argc-generated variables.

faq.question: How does argc compare to other CLI frameworks?
faq.answer: Argc uses pure Bash comments for configuration without external dependencies at runtime.
